Desmond T. Doss.Action: Works with his brother to collect scrap metal to make money, showing cooperation and shared effort.
Responds to his father's question honestly and cheerfully, indicating openness and sincerity.
Pushes a heavy coaster wagon filled with rusty junk metal, demonstrating physical determination and a sense of purpose at a young age.
Engages in entrepreneurial activity by collecting junk metal to sell for money, showing resourcefulness and initiative.
Shows no hesitation or misunderstanding when asked about the purpose of collecting scrap metal, but simply focuses on making money.
Accepts his father's ambiguous permission to continue collecting scrap metal without further questioning, reflecting compliance but not necessarily initiative or independent judgment.
Snatches Mark's hand away and fights him fiercely over a dime, showing no hesitation to hurt his brother in a blind fury.
Snatches Mark's hand away quickly and continues to fight with grit and determination against a bigger opponent.
Lifts a rock over his head in a blind fury with no thought for consequences.
Shows deep concern and horror when observing the illustration of Cain and Abel, indicating his sincere reflection on the value of life and aversion to violence.
Focuses intently on the illustration of the Ten Commandments, particularly on 'Thou shalt not kill,' showing deep thought and moral reflection.
Asks his mother an insightful question about Cain and Abel, indicating curiosity and desire to understand ethical complexities.
Stares at the picture of Cain with a look of horror and tears in his eyes, showing deep emotional sensitivity and empathy.
Waits his turn patiently in the hospital room and is fascinated by medical things, showing interest and respect for others.
Stares fixedly with a look of horror and tears upon realizing the gravity of his moral or ethical mistake.
Shows deep sensitivity and emotional awareness that reflect thoughtful internal processing.
Exhibits keen senses and interest in his environment, such as noticing birds and sounds along railroad tracks.
Is fascinated by medical things and pokes around in a hospital's shelves and cabinets while waiting.
Admits nervousness and inexperience with blood donation, showing openness and sincerity.
Engages in friendly, genuine conversation with nurse Dorothy, laughing and sharing personal feelings about the woods.
Walks ten or twelve miles and gives blood to strangers, thanks Dorothy sincerely.
Gently tries to take the whiskey bottle from his drunken father and offers help getting upstairs.
Silently holds Bertha’s hand while they eat, offering comfort.
Walks ten or twelve miles to give blood to strangers, showing dedication and endurance.
Handles family tensions calmly, gently tries to help his drunken father without escalating conflict.
Engages warmly and politely with Dorothy, showing social intelligence and respect.
Shares a tender moment and first kiss with Dorothy, showing vulnerability and connection.
Catches Dorothy after she gets upset and explains himself, causing her to soften and smile.
Sends Dorothy a note with an orange unexpectedly, sparking confusion then a smile.
Cracks Dorothy up during an intense conversation, showing a playful and engaging nature.
Mentions a potential job raise and salary but shows modesty and concern about bragging.
Explains something to Dorothy after falling off the rope swing, which softens her attitude.
Mentions he is doing a good job at work and might receive a raise and promotion.
Shares a tender moment with Dorothy, displaying love and planning a future together.
Spontaneously pulls over to join a crowd listening anxiously to the President’s speech, showing concern and community awareness.
Responds promptly and appropriately to the news of the attack by pulling over his car without hesitation.
Expresses clear intention and planning for his future with confidence and determination.
Approaches his father in the graveyard with openness and attentiveness despite the somber mood.
Holds back from comforting his father even though he feels the urge to do so.
Approaches his father calmly despite emotional tension, listens carefully and tries to understand his father's feelings and the weight of the situation.
Holds back from comforting his ailing father out of habit and emotional restraint, showing some emotional detachment.
Approaches his angry father tenderly despite harsh words and rejection.
Remains sincere and honest about his decision to enlist even when facing family hostility.
Decides to enlist in the military despite his father's strong opposition and the emotionally charged confrontation.
Attempts to calmly reason and physically approaches his angry father tenderly during a moment of tension and conflict.
Ignores practical advice to avoid the draft by working in an essential defense industry, showing determination to follow his own path.
Asks Dorothy to keep the New Testament close and promises to carry it with him.
Expresses love sincerely to Dorothy before departure.
Takes time to write a heartfelt note to his father despite the rush.
Takes initiative to write a heartfelt note to his father despite being rushed, showing presence of mind and emotional intelligence.
Carefully tucks the New Testament in his pocket after receiving it from Dorothy, showing respect and preparedness.
Jumps onto a moving train confidently despite emotional tension, showing decisiveness and focus.
Expresses uncertainty about his decisions but resolves not to sit idle, indicating some internal conflict though demonstrating commitment.
Writes a heartfelt message to his father despite being rushed and uncertain of communication success.
Attempts to maintain a connection to his family by throwing a note out the train window despite knowing the risk of it being unseen.
Greets Grease Nolan politely and introduces himself calmly.
Declines to join the gambling game when invited by Hollywood.
Greets fellow recruits politely and clearly states his name and origin.
Declines to engage in gambling with the group.
Politely declines to sit in with others, focusing on himself
Laughs at himself after clumsily tying two loops, contributing to a good feeling and group bonding through mutual clumsiness.
Quietly refuses to touch a gun despite pressure and disbelief from others, showing sincerity and trustworthiness to his own values.
Responds respectfully to superiors and corrects himself politely when reminded, indicating good-natured humility and sincerity.
Inadvertently doubles his rope and ties two loops instead of one while learning to tie a bowline.
Blushes and laughs at his own mistake, showing humility and ability to bond with comrades through shared clumsiness.
Refuses to grab a gun when ordered, quietly but firmly expressing his conscientious objection.
Respectfully communicates his concerns and objections to Captain Glover, maintaining proper military decorum despite his difficult position.
Calmly and respectfully explains his religious beliefs and conscientious stance without hostility.
Responds politely to Captain Glover’s hostile accusations and threats without becoming defensive or aggressive.
Refuses to carry a gun or kill due to personal beliefs, showing integrity and sincerity.
Maintains a respectful and composed demeanor despite being rejected and insulted.
Clearly and confidently explains his conscientious objections and religious beliefs to his superior officers without evasion.
Fails to anticipate the resistance and mistrust his beliefs provoke among the officers, leading to immediate rejection and accusations.
Calmly asserts his desire to serve his country despite skepticism and hostility.
Maintains composure despite being publicly ridiculed and isolated by fellow soldiers.
Refuses to engage in violence but seeks to fulfill his duties, showing sincerity and principle.
Insists on serving his country despite not carrying a weapon, demonstrating a strong personal conviction.
Keeps pace with the front of the pack during obstacle course despite being skinny, showing physical capability and skill.
Makes demands viewed as 'ridiculous' by Sgt. Howell, possibly indicating naivety or lack of understanding of military culture.
Remains polite and smiles when Smitty mockingly apologizes about the food shortage, despite the provocation.
Does not complain or react negatively when only leftovers are available to him during the meal.
Pushes himself to the limit during the obstacle course, demonstrating personal determination but also indirectly provoking Smitty’s anger.
Smiles politely after being mocked about his vegetarianism.
Touches bleeding lip calmly and quotes the Bible about turning the other cheek after being slapped by Smitty.
Calmly explains his dietary preference and maintains composure when challenged by Smitty.
Keeps his Bible close for comfort, showing personal discipline and conviction.
Responds to physical aggression with a measured reminder of his beliefs instead of retaliating.
Refrains from fighting back despite provocations and social pressure.
Resists violent retaliation despite provocation and humiliation by Smitty.
Silent endurance and restraint in the face of aggression and mockery.
Internal anger and urge to retaliate physically but consciously chooses not to.
Does not confront Smitty aggressively after Smitty humiliates him by taking his Bible and Dorothy’s picture.
Controls anger and does not physically retaliate against Smitty's provocations despite heavy taunting and loss of his Bible and Dorothy's picture.
Allows Smitty to keep Dorothy's picture and Bible momentarily, maintaining composure rather than escalating conflict.
Internal struggle to maintain identity and principles even when mocked and isolated.
Does not effectively prevent Smitty from taking personal items, potentially seen as a failure to assert himself in a hostile situation.
Firmly and sincerely states his refusal to carry a weapon based on his religious beliefs, despite pressure and misunderstanding.
Defends himself against condescending assumptions by the psychiatrist without insulting or alienating others.
Shows nervousness and anger but remains composed and does not lash out aggressively.
Avoids retaliating against the negative stares and implied hostility of fellow soldiers upon his return.
Firmly refuses to lie or compromise his beliefs during questioning by Colonel Stelzer, showing confidence and strong self-knowledge.
Hesitates before responding but ultimately asserts his refusal to carry a weapon, demonstrating considered and deliberate decision-making.
Returns to barracks feeling vulnerable and self-conscious after interrogation, showing emotional strain under pressure.
Scrubs dirty toilets with a toothbrush despite hostile environment and peers mocking him.
Washes endless dishes with raw hands, silently enduring exclusion from peers' fun and camaraderie.
Does not retaliate or respond negatively to peers calling him a 'weirdo' and 'complete fruitcake'.
Remains unarmed and unburdened during the grueling hike despite physical and social pressure.
Is isolated by fellow soldiers and avoided in the barracks and showers, yet keeps to himself without retaliation.
Shows poor personal area maintenance leading to reprimand from Sergeant Howell.
Continues to keep to himself and refrain from engaging socially, not attempting to improve group cohesion or personal standing.
Does not retaliate or fight back when assaulted by fellow soldiers.
Refuses to identify or blame the men who beat him despite being asked repeatedly.
Claims he just fell instead of admitting he was assaulted.
Does not retaliate or defend himself when physically attacked by multiple men, curls up to protect himself without fighting back.
Refuses to identify attackers and denies assault despite obvious injuries, maintaining composure and control of narrative.
Accepts consequences and risks staying in hostile environment despite threats and lack of support from fellow soldiers and commanding officers.
Admits that the men dislike him and recognize him as responsible for their hardships, but accepts their anger as justified and intended.
Considers Captain Glover coolly when accused of insubordination, showing calm tolerance.
Engages respectfully and sincerely with Colonel Cunningham to request furlough for his wedding, maintaining respect despite hostility.
Considers accusations coolly without losing composure.
Insists on furlough despite knowing he is not rifle qualified.
Faces pressure from superiors but continues to comply with rules and maintain his stance.
Causes frustration among superiors but does not break protocol, showing determination and persistence.
Refuses to pick up a gun despite direct orders and threat of court martial, standing firm on his principles without seeking pity or help from others.
Pleads politely to make a phone call after being led to the stockade.
Refuses to pick up a rifle despite a direct order and threat of court martial.
Maintains composure and does not seek pity or help from fellow soldiers when arrested and led away.
Endures absence from his wedding without bitterness; internalizes his frustration rather than lashing out at others.
Expresses overwhelming frustration and despair through destructive behavior in solitude.
Acknowledges lawyer's advice with humility and without hostility, though clearly miserable.
Paces in his cell and breaks down in a scream and destructive outburst of frustration and anger.
Shrugs and sinks into misery after lawyer advises him to plead guilty for a dishonorable discharge.
Sits calmly reading the Bible despite stressful circumstances.
Respectfully responds to Captain Glover despite the harsh tone.
Expresses sincere commitment to giving his life to save his men.
Stands firm in his convictions and confidently states he is prepared to give his life for his men despite pressure from Captain Glover.
Does not immediately respond when Captain Glover interrupts him, showing respectful hesitation rather than assertiveness.
Refuses to plead guilty and accept an honorable discharge despite threats, showing sincerity and commitment to his beliefs.
Allows Dorothy to comfort him in jail, openly showing vulnerability and trusting her.
Speaks honestly and respectfully to Dorothy, even when they disagree, maintaining civility.
Acknowledges his possible pride but frames it as wanting to be a man Dorothy could be proud of, revealing self-awareness and a desire for genuine connection.
Raised his voice during argument, which made Dorothy seethe.
Dorothy puts her arms around him and holds him close after he admits being scared of failing.
Sits alone lost in thought in cell, showing vulnerability but no interaction with others.
Engages in light-hearted banter with Sgt. Howell about betting odds, showing friendly rapport.
Observes soldiers practicing bayonet drill silently with a thoughtful, possibly empathetic expression.
Sits alone in his cell, lost in thought, reflects on fear of failing, then takes initiative to ask for his lawyer.
Watches soldiers confidently practicing bayonet drill and seems contemplative and aware of realities of war.
Engages Sgt. Howell with calm and a bit of dry humor about pool odds on him quitting.
Shows vulnerability through the unspoken pain when refusing to attend, indicating sincere emotional depth.
Stands firm on his principles in court by refusing to plead guilty, despite pressure and lack of support.
Initially prepared to enter a guilty plea, but then changes his mind and stands up for himself in court.
Seems to lack support in the courtroom, sitting alone without anyone present for him.
Expresses sincere desire to serve his country without carrying a weapon, emphasizing saving lives and protecting fellow soldiers.
Respectfully answers the court's questions without confrontation or disrespect.
Calmly accepts the serious situation of facing a court martial despite legal counsel's advice to reconsider.
Explains his motivation clearly and sincerely under pressure, showing thoughtfulness and composure.
Wipes sweaty hands on his pants and admits to working out his feelings on his feet, indicating some nervousness and uncertainty.
Hugs Dorothy gratefully after the court ruling.
Savors a tender moment with Dorothy, sharing mutual love and support.
Successfully maintains his conscientious objector status legally and resumes duties as combat medic.
Expresses genuine surprise and gratitude at Dorothy's intervention.
Focuses on emotional connection and personal resolve rather than immediate tactical concerns.
Kisses Dorothy tenderly despite her emotional threat, showing affection and sincerity.
Walks alone at the rear of the company as an unarmed medic, carrying heavy supplies despite being shunned by fellow soldiers.
Carries a full field backpack plus three plasma sets, a surgical kit, and two canteens, showing preparedness for medical duties.
Walks alone in the rear, separated from the men who shun him due to his conscientious objector status and unarmed status.
Remains the only man unarmed in the entire US army, which could be seen as lacking conventional self-defense competence but aligns with his principles.
Takes off his helmet in respectful silence along with others when seeing returning battered soldiers and dead men in trucks.
Removes his helmet along with others, showing respect and composure amid grim circumstances.
Immediately hurries to aid wounded soldiers despite danger and confusion.
Tells Bruno not to speak and save his breath, focused on saving him rather than comforting.
Recognizes the urgency and hurries to assist wounded soldiers immediately after the grenade attack.
Checks pulse and tries to assess condition despite shock and chaos, showing presence of mind under pressure.
His expression doesn’t comfort the shaken wounded soldier, indicating possible difficulty in emotionally supporting while performing medical tasks.
Swiftly and skillfully treats and stabilizes wounded soldier Bruno despite his own anxiety.
Treats a wounded Japanese enemy soldier despite danger and orders to abandon him.
Quietly insists on his duty to care for all wounded regardless of their side.
Quickly injects morphine, applies tourniquet, sets up and administers plasma IV to Bruno, effectively stabilizing him.
Commands the stretcher team to evacuate the wounded efficiently.
Despite shaking hands, completes medical interventions calmly and competently.
Without hesitation, treats a wounded enemy soldier despite the risk and hostility from comrades.
Shows moral courage in prioritizing his job to care for all wounded, regardless of enemy status.
Sits by himself, ignored by the rest of the company, quietly eating cold K rations.
Receives medical supplies from Schecter and asks sincerely if the bandages are okay.
Listens carefully to Schecter’s warnings about the danger medics face and silently prepares by taking black tape for camouflage.
Responds respectfully and calmly to Captain Glover's harsh and dismissive order without argument.
Responds respectfully and affirmatively to Captain Glover despite the harsh warning and conflicting orders regarding his beliefs.
No indication of hesitation or visible doubt when confronted with pressure to abandon his principles and conform to violent combat expectations.
Closes his eyes and says a silent prayer, whispers 'Amen' which others notice.
Hurries towards a wounded soldier despite nearby mortar fire and personal injury.
Notices his own blood with a mix of fear and delight, then wipes it off and continues forward.
Closes his eyes, says a silent prayer, then quickly tucks his Bible away and prepares to move at signal.
Despite being hit by sharp limestone shards and bleeding, quickly wipes own blood and plunges back toward the line.
Runs into heavy enemy fire to aid a wounded soldier despite danger.
Reassures the wounded soldier verbally, promising not to leave him.
Launches himself over the berm and runs to aid a severely wounded soldier despite heavy machine gun fire and grenade attacks.
Quickly administers morphine and applies a tourniquet to the wounded soldier under intense combat conditions.
Shows determination and calm by talking to the wounded soldier and reassuring him even in chaos.
Ignores the warning from Schecter to move on and chooses to stay with and aid the wounded soldier.
Earnestly talks with the wounded soldier, showing interest in his background to comfort him.
Protects the wounded soldier by pushing him down and using his own body to shield him from an imminent explosion.
Positions himself between the wounded soldier and the cliff face during their dangerous descent, trying to absorb harm himself.
Injects wounded soldier with morphine and applies a tourniquet quickly and effectively.
Calmly converses with the wounded soldier to keep him conscious and reassured.
Carries wounded soldier to the edge of a 70-foot cliff knowing the dangers involved.
Wraps a bandage on his own injured hand and simultaneously tries to secure the wounded soldier with limited mobility.
Uses his body to shield the wounded soldier from an incoming unexploded mortar shell, showing presence of mind under extreme stress.
Descends a swinging rope down a cliff while controlling the injured soldier despite limited control.
Attempts to use his body to shield the soldier from collisions with the cliff face during the dangerous descent.
Runs alongside stretcher bearers carrying wounded soldier back to aid station despite personal danger.
Watches doctor treat wounded soldier without complaint despite harsh criticism about soldier's chances.
Accepts Smitty's presence in his foxhole with surprise but pleasure, showing receptiveness to companionship.
Commands for stretchers to evacuate the wounded soldier immediately after narrowly escaping death himself.
Runs alongside stretcher bearers to assist with carrying the wounded soldier.
Observes the doctor's treatment critically and does not intervene despite his own medical knowledge, showing awareness of his role and limits.
Stops in shock upon witnessing his company’s chaotic retreat, showing human vulnerability but does not freeze or abandon duty.
Calmly eats a minimal meal in a foxhole under mortar fire, exhibiting self-control and acceptance of harsh conditions.
Welcomes Smitty into his foxhole and interacts calmly, showing social composure under stress.
Prays quietly to himself during stressful moments, showing sincerity and inner calm.
Responds gently to Smitty's cynical comments about prayer and war, maintaining patience and calm.
Accepts the torn photo of Dorothy from Smitty without resentment, appreciating the gesture and showing forgiveness.
Does not react negatively when Smitty admits that he still finds Desmond 'weird' despite the kindness shown.
Responds insightfully to Smitty about camouflage by identifying it correctly, showing situational awareness.
Calmly prays to maintain composure under stress, demonstrating mental resilience and confidence.
Keeps focused on comfort and morale by cherishing the photo of Dorothy, which helps maintain psychological stability.
Does not engage in weapon preparation or aggressive behavior when others do, instead focuses on prayer and inner strength.
Volunteers first to help tie heavy cargo nets to move men and supplies faster despite danger.
Mumbles a prayer quietly while climbing, showing sincerity and internal calm under pressure.
Mumbles a prayer while climbing the ladder, showing focus and calm under pressure.
Secures the rope carefully and helps hoist cargo net for others, demonstrating reliability and supportiveness.
Keeps head down and acts fearlessly, prioritizing safety and mission over personal glory.
Leads by example in pulling cargo net and working collaboratively with Smitty and Jones.
Friendly interaction as Smitty joins him and grins for the camera; Desmond shows no signs of negative reaction.
Kneels immediately beside wounded Schecter, assesses injury calmly, and administers aid while respecting Schecter's wish to avoid morphine.
Quickly assesses Schecter’s serious leg wound, decides on morphine but respects Schecter’s refusal, and applies a careful tourniquet allowing safe evacuation.
Hurries after his company to participate actively in the charge on the bunker, showing situational awareness and engagement in the battle.
Smiles tightly and nods, uncomfortable with fellow soldiers' affectionate praise.
Shows genuine concern and devastated guilt over a fellow medic's death after learning his friend died in pain.
Receives affectionate praise from fellow soldiers for saving them and remains humble and uncomfortable with the praise.
Shows concern and inquiries about the condition of a fellow medic Schecter immediately after the battle.
Experienced guilt and regret for his friend's death, showing emotional sensitivity but no evidence of negligence or incompetence.
Quietly admits to his mistake and expresses sorrow over Irv's death to Smitty.
Modestly deflects praise and attributes success to God rather than himself.
Remains quiet and introspective while others celebrate their success.
Carefully heats coffee over a small flame, showing resourcefulness and caution in a combat environment.
Admits to having made a mistake leading to the death of a comrade (Irv), showing accountability but suggesting a momentary lapse or error.
Remains quiet and reflective even after a major success in battle, indicating humility and possibly careful internal processing rather than overconfidence.
Immediately reacts to protect Smitty by fighting off multiple Japanese soldiers to defend his comrade.
Hugs and comforts his sobbing mother after she has been hurt by his father.
Opens up honestly to Smitty about his troubled family past and his father's abusive behavior.
Reactively attacks a Japanese soldier with a broken rifle in self-defense.
Grabs a barrel and fights a soldier, uses a broken rifle found in the mud to defend himself.
Raises rifle instinctively when threatened by a Japanese Officer with a pistol, showing quick reflexes under pressure.
Shows hesitation or distraction momentarily due to a surreal vision of the Japanese officer resembling his father, which may impact effectiveness in battle.
Exhibits controlled breathing and alertness after waking from a nightmare during battle, remaining aware of surroundings.
Expresses distrust or fear of weapons despite familiarity, indicating internal conflict or anxiety.
Frozen with fear as a child witnessing violence, but obediently takes the gun from Bertha to hide it, protecting others from harm.
As an eight-year-old, he freezes in fear watching a violent fight escalating with a gun involved.
Despite his fear, obediently takes a pistol from his mother and runs off to hide it before police arrive.
Later admits to hiding the gun in the woods instead of throwing it away to a trusted confidant, showing cautious decision-making.
Endures brutal whipping from his father without crying out, showing emotional resilience and self-control.
Runs through the woods after his release, determined and focused, indicating persistence and goal orientation.
Examines his father’s gun carefully, appreciating its mechanism and power, demonstrating curiosity and a capacity for understanding complex objects.
Harbors a vengeful desire to kill his father, reflecting emotional impulsiveness that may hinder clear-headedness.
Raises a gun threateningly at his father in anger but ultimately does not shoot and walks away, choosing forgiveness over violence.
Throws the gun into the river making a promise never to use it again, showing commitment to peace despite personal pain.
Admits he is not holier or better than others, showing humility and sincerity.

Raises a gun and points it at his father, showing intense emotional conflict but does not pull the trigger and instead walks away, throwing the gun into the river and making a solemn promise never to touch a gun again.
Despite extreme emotional pressure and potential danger, makes a deeply principled and resolute personal decision, demonstrating self-control and conviction.
Does not engage physically with his father despite provocation, instead chooses non-violent resolution in a highly charged moment.
In the battlefield situation, appears aware of danger (mortar shells and grenade) and remains conscious of surroundings, cooperating with Smitty.
Rushes to defend and attempt to save Smitty by attacking the Japanese soldier, showing loyalty and protectiveness.
Becomes weeping with fury and frustration at failing to save Smitty, revealing emotional sincerity and deep concern for others.
Drags a fallen comrade's body (Smitty) back toward safety under heavy fire.
Returns to the killing field to help wounded soldiers despite opportunity to escape.
Applies quick, effective first aid to a soldier with a sucking chest wound.
Refuses to retreat with others and instead asks stretcher bearers to leave their dressings for further aid.
Thinks quickly to use a plastic patch from his poncho to effectively seal a soldier's sucking chest wound, demonstrating resourcefulness and medical skill in extreme conditions.

Despite intense fear and the chaos of battle, chooses to stay behind and continue treating and rescuing wounded soldiers rather than retreating with the others, showing confidence and focus on his mission.
Applies a tourniquet and drags wounded soldiers back under fire despite great personal risk.
Hesitates when a wounded soldier begs not to be left but reassures him he will return.
Invents a method to lower wounded soldiers safely and more efficiently down a cliff, showing care and concern for others' lives.
Risking his life to lower wounded soldiers down a cliff despite orders and danger.
Ignoring Captain Glover’s command to get down and instead continuing to rescue wounded.
Persisting in moving toward wounded soldiers under heavy enemy fire despite fear and injury.
Secures wounded soldier with rope and carefully lowers him down a cliff to safety despite the dangerous conditions.
Ignores Captain Glover's order to come down from the cliff and continues rescue efforts.
Attempts to crawl towards wounded soldiers under heavy enemy fire using terrain for cover.
Momentarily paralyzed with fear when under machine gun fire.
Despite fear and intense enemy fire, he risks his life to rescue wounded soldiers, using his poncho to distract the enemy.
Refuses to leave wounded soldiers behind, staying on the battlefield when others have retreated.
Risking his own life to save wounded American soldiers under sniper and machine gun fire.
Using a dead Japanese soldier’s helmet with a Red Cross symbol to deceive the enemy and protect the wounded.
Uses quick thinking to disguise a dead Japanese soldier with a helmet marked by the Red Cross to draw enemy fire and create a distraction.
Remains focused under sniper threat and machine gun fire, acting decisively to rescue wounded men.
Responds calmly to unexpected sniper shot on the helmet by immediately removing the dead soldier’s body from danger and sprinting to rescue.
Drags wounded American soldier towards safety despite heavy enemy fire.
Notices wounded Japanese soldier moaning but hesitates, torn between continuing mission and helping enemy.
Moves quickly and skillfully across dangerous terrain, dragging a wounded soldier to safety under fire.
Carefully approaches wounded soldiers from different directions to avoid enemy fire.
Shows hesitation when deciding whether to leave a wounded enemy soldier to die or help him.
Moves back to tend and dress the bullet wound of a wounded Japanese soldier despite the danger to himself.
Makes a calculated decision to expose himself to danger to rescue wounded soldiers.
Successfully carries multiple wounded men to safety repeatedly under heavy fire.
Imports the use of rope to safely lower wounded soldiers down the cliff edge, demonstrating resourcefulness.
Despite exhaustion and injuries, continues rescue efforts with determination.
Focuses on saving one last man (Smitty), even though he is already dead, showing compassion but possibly a momentary emotional choice.
After exhausting rescue efforts, leaves the ridge alone, physically and mentally drained.
Removes a bloody uniform and carefully tries to wipe the blood from his pocket Bible before putting on a replacement uniform, showing respect and reverence.
Sits alone in his foxhole, tired and wounded, yet silently receives food offerings from comrades who quietly support him.
Successfully rescues many wounded soldiers under fire, completed the task of getting all men to safety despite severe physical and mental exhaustion.
Changes into a washed and bleached uniform of a dead soldier, taking care with his belongings and briefly pausing to wipe his Bible, showing presence of mind in a chaotic situation.
Sits alone in his foxhole, fatigued and bloodied, accepting food offerings silently from comrades without initiating interaction or commands.
The men refuse to assault the ridge without Desmond accompanying them, showing the trust and respect he commands.
Sits quietly reading his Bible alone behind a tomb, reflecting a calm and sincere demeanor.
Indicates his strong faith and personal conviction by observing it is his Sabbath, which influences the soldiers' decision.
The troops refuse to advance without Desmond’s participation, showing their faith in his ability to accompany them into battle.
Desmond quietly reads his Bible behind shelter, showing calmness and preparation on the eve of a dangerous mission.
Captain Glover notes that Desmond is hesitant or unsure when asked if he understands the importance of joining the mission despite it being his Sabbath.
Pauses the assault to pray despite pressure, showing deep sincerity and concern for others' spiritual well-being.
Takes time before an assault to pray and mentally prepare despite pressure from superiors.
Causes a delay in the military operation by pausing to complete his prayer, risking operational timing.
Prays quietly, shows sincere inner conflict over breaking a promise, asks for forgiveness, takes responsibility alone.
Expresses internal conflict but chooses to act on a sense of duty by rejoining his men despite personal reservations.
Quietly leads by example, signaling readiness and moving confidently with the assault team.
Pushes fellow soldiers out of the way to protect them from an incoming grenade, sacrificing his own safety.
Pushes his fellow soldiers out of the way to protect them from the incoming grenade, tries to kick the grenade away despite the danger.
Screams with pain and is injured seriously by the grenade blast, indicating vulnerability in physical resilience under fire.
Despite severe injury and pain, shows concern by patting his shirt pocket indicating the presence of his bible.
Unable to speak clearly due to injury but attempts to communicate something meaningful and personal.
Manages to keep his composure enough to reach for his bible and tries to communicate despite severe injury and blood loss.
Severely wounded to the point of being incapacitated and unable to speak clearly.
Allows Captain Glover to hold his hand during a critical moment, showing acceptance and trust.
Manages a smile despite severe injuries and pain.
Despite severe injuries and near death, he manages a smile when reassured by Captain Glover, showing mental resilience and quiet confidence.
Unable to prevent himself from coughing up blood and severely wounded, indicating physical vulnerability but no direct incompetence.
Remains modest about his heroics, giving credit to his Faith and honoring fallen soldiers.
Awarded the Medal of Honor for courage under fire, recognized for heroics without seeking credit.
Attributes success solely to faith, minimizing his own skill and actions.
